When you get in the flow of playing this game can be quite satisfying. Shooting the bow can feel quite good, and it's nice to notice you get better. But it still feels quite unfished.

You only unlock new checkpoints every 5 levels, and those 5th levels often feel very unfair, suddenly introducing new mechanics, that you can't practice again without replaying all the ones before that. I understand that in martial arts repetition is everything, but let me decide on that myself in stead of forcing it. I'm trying to just have fun.

32926093.review:
Holopoint is a fast archery combat game which demands a lot physical movement, precision and quick re-orientation work of its players. Playing this right causes solid sweating after few minutes. The learning curve is quiet good and the fun playing it is going to increase with it.

Persanally this is one of my favorite VR games now. It has not much content but the thing it does are mostly right. It has high replay value if you see it like me as a game for workout.

The most impressiv thing which did this game for me was to break my „gamepad-lethargy“, how i call it now. Decades of playing just with keyboard & mouse or with a gamepad teached me to press a button or stick to move around and avoid to be hit by bullets. In VR games my reaction time was sooo sloooow and in many situation i just stood dump around and got hit and was frustrated. I could have moved a step right or left but somehow it didnt work. And then in Holopoint there was the moment then I jumped, yes JUMPED, to avoid a projectile. And now I constantly move around - using the little room I have in VR to it‘s full extend – to get the best angle to shoot or get to the savest spot in the room. I crouch, twist or bend my body to avoid projectiles.  No other VR game demand this much movement from its players than Holopoint. The constant necessary flow of movement, re-orientation, aiming and shooting is exhilarating and chilling in the same time.

Sure there are a few downsides in this game. Biggest is the poor bow mechanic compared with games like QuiVR. In QuiVR shooting with the bow fast feels natural and it is possible to headshot enemies over large distances. Using the bow in Holopoint feels awkward in the first place but gets better after a short time. My advice for people who come from QuiVR: look in the option menu and try around different settings, this helped me to get better results. The main reason for the awkward feeling is that the grip is too much below the center of the bow. It feels like you dont hold the grip but the bow arm below it. I dont know why the developer did this. They might had a reason and in time i got used to it. Now 95% shots are hits. There are also other things which could be adressed with little effort and would make the game even better. I hope the developer is going to put more work in this jewel to create a true tressure :)

(Please excuse grammar failure and misspells. English is not my mother language.)

31438109.review:
A year and a bit on this is still one of my favourite VR games. The mechanics are simple; shoot a box and it explodes and shoots a projectile back at you, which you have to dodge (in later levels, samurai also steadily approach you and you have to shoot them before they get to you). Simple though they may be, they're tuned perfectly. You're always focusing on the next target, balancing the time to line up a shot with the urgency of the two boxes behind you that you can hear are getting ready to explode (boxes left un-shot will explode and shoot at you of their own volition: still dodge-able but much harder and less predictable).

The sound design is also excellent. As boxes near their exploding point, they make an unintrusive whooshing sound that builds to a crescendo. This is both long enough and balanced enough that you know exactly how long you have. It's also very well placed in the space around you, so you know what direction it's in. Excellent soundtrack as well.

The game is very physical. It is the only VR game I've come across that actually builds up a sweat. By some accounts the game can be cheesed a bit if you're methodical with dodges, but it's equivalent to using a dictionary in scrabble; it may give better results, but it's no fun. It's best played leaping and spinning around like a ninja. Treat it that way and it will entirely fulfil your Matrix fantasies.

I always see it reccommended for new users but rarely evangalised, which I think is a crying shame. I think it's one of the most mechanically complete games available for VR. 

10/10 would arrow-ninja again.

N.B. There's two different aiming mechanics. I highly reccommend switching it to 'two-handed', as this aims like a real bow (straight line from rear hand to front hand). The default mode uses the orientation of your front hand to aim and doesn't feel natural; your hand won't be where the string is. Any negative comparisons to archery in The Lab etc have probably not enabled this, as it makes the aiming systems identical. Wish it was the default though.

31032882.review:
I purchased a VR system as a means of avoiding becoming sedentary after I started working from home (at computer all day).  Of all the games I purchased, Holopoint is probably the top for getting my heartrate up.  The first levels are very easy, just introducing you to the game.  Once you hit level 25 though (you can start a play session at any level you have reached in increments of 5) the game is surprisingly fast paced and tiring.

When things get intense, I find myself crouched on the ground firing arrows and spinning on my heels like Legolas in LOTR movies.  The game is definitely better with a large play space and I highly encourage some kind of ceiling cable management system to keep the cords from getting tangled around your feet.  This is definitely a Room Scale game.  There is no front/back, the game takes place all around you and above you.

My current plan is to add a weighted vest once I am able to beat the game, though I still can't seem to reach level 30.

30989222.review:
For a more in-depth look (and some high level gameplay) check out my video review: https://youtu.be/bRgVU7zyuXE

Holopoint is like if SuperHot had sex with Space Pirate Simulator and Geometry Wars is in the closet watching… but there is no slow motion and you can only use a bow and arrow. Is that helpful? I think that describes this game pretty well after playing it for 50+ hours. At its heart it’s another wave based survival game that strongly prioritizes your own reactive movements above all else. Yes, it’s important to be accurate but you can miss an arrow here and there without the game ending. You yourself can only take two hits until it’s Game Over, so getting the Hell out of the way is a bit more important than landing your shots. That being said, I’d try to make every arrow count anyway as that’s pretty key for your hitting a new high score. 

Chasing after your high score is very addictive as no matter how low your score starts there is just something about knowing you’re a faster and a better virtual bowman than the dude you just toppled on the leaderboard. There is a downside: good luck not tangling your Vive’s cable. No, seriously, good luck. You’re going to need it. Based on how often enemies attack you from behind it would be a damn miracle for your not to have a horrifically tangled mess by the time you’re done with an intense play session. 

Still, even with that negative, I’d urge you to buy Holopoint if any of this sounds vaguely interesting. It may not be the best bow and arrow simulator on the Vive (though I intend to find out what is) but it sure does make you feel like a badass… perhaps more than any other game before it. I’d just probably do some stretches or something beforehand though, you don’t want to pull a hammy.

29274629.developer_response:
Thank you for your feedback.

This response is In-order to help clarify points made in the above review.

Holopoint is design to have more content than most players will reach. Throughout the sixty waves, the game offers a variety of enemy types, bosses, environments, and obtainable bows. Upon community request, a custom game editor has been added for workout routines and quick sessions. If your feeling competitive, the global leaderboard scores you against the world in an insane battle for the top.

Holopoint is not for everyone. The game is designed to require a fair amount of agility, awareness, and personal training to reach the end. This puts the challenge directly on the player to train personal skills and abilities. If you have not completed the first set of waves we recommend giving it a shot.

Thanks again and happy gaming!

26450017.review:
Fantastic game. 

The game is pretty straightforward, but there are a few obscure things that aren't pointed out but is not really necessary to know to progress. (Health Counter are a pair of candles on the side of the room, you have 2 lives, and they extinguish as you get hit. Also some targets don't shoot back because you got a perfect shot dead center) There's also a settings menu so you can kind of adjust how the bow operates to your liking. (You can make it fixed to the direction of your bow hand or fixed to your arrow hand when aiming)

Some tips: Remember to look up when you don't see any targets. Lower the music audio in the settings (but don't mute everything) because enemies have audio cues as they approach or ready a shot. Use the 3D audio to pinpoint the imminent threat. The bigger the room the easier it'll be, but you can play this game with a medium sized room too. 

It's a lot of fun, and you end up moving a lot. It has impressed every one of my friends so far. At the end of the day, it's a wave defense game, but it's a really fun one and makes good use of VR.

I do wish there was a way to practice boss fights, because I'm pretty stuck on the first one and I think it's because I suck at hitting moving targets of that size.

25073045.review:
I cannot reccomend this game.

I love archery.  There are so many nuances to being a skilled archer, some of which includes leading your targets, accounting for arrow trajectory, and tracking moving objects, but this game has none of that.  You will spend your entire time in a small room firing at stationary targets.  Even the samurais walk directly toward you, so none of the above really comes into play.  This game does not take advantage of any of the mechanics that make archery so cool.

24733650.review:
Definitely my favourite VR game yet! At the time of this review, Steam says I have a bit over an hour in the game, which seems weird to me because I definietly feel like its been at least twice that.

Anyway, this is very fun! It becomes a lot more than just point and shoot, as the floaty squares shoot projectiles at you when you destroy them, and explode if you leave them for long enough without destroying them. You end up shooting and dodging, and constantly turning to check behind and above you for newly spawned floaty cubes (not really sure what to call them!)

Every 5 waves you reach a sort of "checkpoint", ie when you die you can restart at that level - but only if you have reached that level at least once before.

Once you reach wave 10 the dudes start to spawn. At first they seem less dangerous than the floaty cubes, as they move slowly and dont shoot at you, but I found them harder to hit, and if they reach you it is actually quite terrifying when they swing their sword in your face! It really gives motivation to improve your aim and shoot them before they get too close.

This game is not yet perfect - my main complaint would be that the default aim is too low. It takes quite a bit of getting used to - I feel like I need to move my bowstring hand further down than I should just to get the arrow to fire straight and perpendicular to my body. As with almost all VR games at this point, it does feel like it could use a bit more work, but is still incredibly fun as it is at the moment.

The constant doding, moving and shooting can get quite tiring. Whilst not especially fit, I'm in OK shape, and I find this game gets me fairly sweaty after playing for a while. I normally need to go take a shower straight after playing! I'm hoping this will help me get a bit fitter though, as it definitely feels like a mini-workout playing this.

All in all a very fun game, and I definitely recommend you purchase it - unless, that is, you have the minimum amount of space to play in.
This game requires you move around a bit, and initially I only had the minimum area to play in with my Vive, and I feared for my controllers with the amount I was smashing them into things (thankfully they are still fine).
Once I managed to upgrade my space into a larger area it becamse a lot easier to play the game.
You can still try play it in a tiny space, but its really hard and not too fun, so you might need to give this a miss if you are playing in a tiny space.

24093322.review:
You duck, you dodge, you draw, you lean to the side to avoid a bullet, you shoot. It's becoming frantic, they're getting close. You're going so fast your arrows have literally lit on fire. You're hot and sweating, you're almost to the end of the wave. And then, as you pivot to take out a humming square that's about to shoot, your Vive's power connector yanks out of the box because you've been spinning around so much that the tether is all twisted. You lost.

That was my biggest enemy in this game, stepping on the cord, getting the cord tangled, unplugging the cord because all the slack was taken up by twists. Even my earbuds managed to get caught and pull out of my ears once. The game is fantastic, it's one of my favorite experiences so far. But it really shows off the limitations of the Vive's cabling. Maybe it's just me, maybe other people have a pulley or something to keep things organized.

But in the first twenty minutes of any session, when there's slack in the cord and you're not sweaty, it's a ludicrously fun game. A few other games have "dodge" mechanics like this, but those other games make your hitbox so large that you can't dodge all that well (they have block mechanics too, usually). This one has no block, you can only dodge; and the dodging is very precise - you only need to move your head half a foot to the left and a bullet will miss you. It feels right, it's satisfying, and it's worth the experience.

TLDR; Game is awesome fun and very physical. 100% immersion, bow position in left hand could be a little better, but is good enough. I recommend purchasing it, $15USD isn't too much for such a neat experience. 

Bought this game yesterday, and I've only played it about 45 minutes so far. This number *WILL* increase. 

Firstly this game is rather awesome. I've played maybe 15 VR games, and this one is the first to make me squeal like a little girl. The archery is almost spot on (more on that later), the waves of enemies build up nicely, and there's more variety in oppoents than Space Pirate Trainer for example.

The Enemies: First off you start with some harmless looking cubes, which shoot things at you. These aren't too bad, and if you just dodge they seem to go away even if you miss. Then all of the sudden there's so many cubes, all you can think of is "F*** I hope there's not one behind me!!" Things calm down for a second when the next enemies are introduced, a swordsman. He doesn't shoot thigns at you and just comes at you with a raised sword. Relentlessly. And before you know it you've now gotta pay attention to where the sword guys are while the cubes fire more missiles at you. It's pandemonium. There are more enemies, and at least one boss, but I'll let you find them. 

Movement: Takes advantage of roomscale. Enough said really, although I have a roughly 2x2.5m space and I wouldnt want to be playing in any smaller, because have I mentioned that you move. Like a lot, jumping, dodging, weaving (falling over...)  I'd having a guess that this is probabaly the most active game on VR currently, and defintely the most active I've played.

Combat: The archery is good, one handed mode is sort of like The Lab, and two handed mode is more how real life is like. Sadly, I wasn't fully happy with the way the controller was mapped to the bow, it feels like you're holding it too low. About 5-10cm (2-4" for you Americans) too low. You can adjust to this, but I just feel that the archery would be perfect if it was changed a little. Devs, maybe an option to change the grip height on the bow? 

Overall, this is an awesome game. I love it. If you like the archery in The Lab and games like Space Pirate Trainer, I recommend picking it up.  

Performance: On my system this game works really well, and is fairly easy on hardware. My GPU's don't run VR terribly well, but at no point did I experience any desire for more framerate. Note: I haven't tried in single GPU mode, but in every other VR game that I've had performance issues with, one card is better than two. 
i5 2500k @ 4.6GHz
16GB DDR3 RAM @ 1333MHz
AMD 7970 GHz edition x2 (Crossfire)

跟音盾一样必入的游戏~它与《The Lab》里面的射箭不同，这个是超级消耗体力的游戏，并且需要一定的技巧。
正所谓熟能生巧，除了体力，也需要熟悉各兵种的属性。关卡开始只有方块，我们尽量练习能射中正中心，因为如果不是射正中心，它在破碎后会有碎片反射回来，我们需要迅速避开，从而更消耗体力了，而射中正中则不会出现此情况。后面关卡会出现持刀的兵种，它们只会近身伤害，练习一小关后，开始配搭方块+持刀兵，难度增加了不少，我选择先击杀方块，持刀兵因为不会反射，相对好解决（巧妙利用重叠时一箭双雕哦）；然后这关会出现BOSS，这个boss嘛，看RP，能击中要害的话，容易过关，如果你老射不中的话，这里真的要花心思，不断重复10-14关，超级累啊。
到了第四大关，就是15小关开始，又出现新型兵种，就是身体语言超级活跃的兵种，在你面前跳来跳去蹦来蹦去，耍猴一样，也不容易射中他们，还会远程攻击你呢！目前我就玩到这里，我也分享到这里吧。

An extremely fun and challenging arcade style wave survival game, highly recommended!  Warning, you WILL work up a sweat.

Pros:
-Slaughter cubes and samurai that assault you from all direction, and even from straight above you!
-Cubes have like a 90% chance shoot back upon death which is a nice touch, it keeps you on your toes
-You will get a work out guaranteed
-Eventually you will become very good at pinpointing the enemies and fragging them, it feels really badass
-Plenty of levels to beat/unlock with a global leaderboard system
-Devs are regularly updating the game, it's a purchase I feel really good about making
-$15 feels just about right for the quality of the game and the frequent updates.  I got it 50% off as an early adopter which in retrospect was an absolute steal

Cons:
-You will get sweaty, take breaks and perhaps get a VRCover
-A slower practice/relaxing mode would be nice for days when I don't want to work my ass off
-Graphics are pretty lackluster, come in with low expectations

Other:
-With a good shot, you can hit the projectiles that the cubes fire at you

My negatives are small though, and this game is definitely fun if your looking for an dedicated archery game outside of the Lab's archery.

Holopoint is a simple concept executed well. 
Since buying the HTC Vive, this is the only game I keep coming back to. It's fun and is a real workout, especially at the later levels.

Overall this is my favourite VR game, I keep coming back to play it and it's the first thing I show people that come round to try out VR.

23278506.review:
Best VR game I have.  Requires VR to exist, and takes full advantage of room-size VR.  Highly recommend it to anyone.

The point of games like this is to trick me, the lazy geek, into exercise.  For that reason, the dodge mechanics become very important.

Holopoint requires a fairly significant amount of dodging.  Part of what makes that possible is the single shots coming from bad guys that don't track your movement.  Something shoots, I see it, and move out of the way.  Eventually too many things shoot and I die, but the single shot mechanics "work" for me and keep me active. (currently ranked #530 or so... so I don't suck at the game... or there are only 540 people playing:) )

Those jerks with the swords are pretty exciting too.  Nothing like turning around and having one of them inside my movement box because I forgot he was sneaking up on me until that point.

My only con is the lack of instructions.  I've poked around and couldn't find anything specifically stating how to play.  Its not that difficult, but... 

Why does a box sometimes not shoot?  (bullseye hit vs not)
Why do my arrows sometime start burning?  (No Clue.  Speed of shots?  # of hits in a second?  what?)
Do burning arrows DO anything except look cool? (I don't THINK so)
Can I dodge the sword swings? (I don't think so, but that would be cool if I could)
Can I shoot ANY incoming missile (stars, crap from that one boss, etc?)
Does putting my arrow in the way of an incoming missile actually count as an intercept? (seemed like that happened once)

As an aside, I wish I could search for "Room-sized" ONLY games.  Things that don't have "standing" or "seated" as options.

23147618.review:
In my opinion, this is one of the must-have games right now for the Vive, because it really demonstrates how fun and immersive a room-scale game can be. The environment, controls, and gameplay are all great, and it will give you a serious workout. As other reviewers have said, in no time at all, this game will have you dodging enemy attacks and picking off a room full of targets one by one like something straight out of an action movie. Great times.

The only problem I've had isn't a problem with the game at all, but with the Vive's cable. This game gets so intense and requires so much movement that I've tripped more than a few times, and even ripped my HDMI plug out of its socket once. It's still a great experience and well worth the price; you just have to be real careful with the cord.

As a final note, I noticed a few other reviewers complaining about the bow and arrow dynamics (saying they weren't as good as in The Lab), which almost made me not buy this game. Not sure if the game has been updated since those reviews or if those people just didn't know what to expect, but as someone who's shot a lot of real bows, I can tell you the dynamics are perfect. They're also adjustable in the settings if you don't like them for whatever reason.

23147243.review:
While looking for new things to try on the Vive, I've heard *so* many comments of the form "This game doesn't look like much, but give it a try." So, so much this.

I loved trying out theBlu and getting a first sense for the whole VR thing. And then trying out The Lab and seeing how interacting with VR worlds could seem natural and just... real. But they both felt like the type of thing that would be more useful for "Hey, you have to check *this* out" when friends come over, rather than any sort of lasting experience.

And then there's this little $8 game. Even though it requires a high-end PC and an $800 headset thingie, it somehow reminds me of some of the very first video games, in a very very good way. It's just pure gameplay. There's no gimmicks, no plot, no nothing, just you and a high score list, but the gameplay is so damn *fun* that that's all you care about.

As (many) other reviews on the interwebs say, yes, it does in fact make you feel like a badass. When you duck underneath a cyber-samurai's sword swing while drawing back your bow to take out another one off to the side, yeah, you feel ridiculously cool. And that's because Holopoint just strips away everything and somehow makes you feel you're *there*. It is so viscerally satisfying.

A couple of things that could impact your Vive's livelihood. First, after playing this for 15-20 minutes, I started to sweat a bit. Which hasn't come close to happening with any other VR thing I've played. Maybe a little bit with the (similarly simple but beautiful) Space Pirate Trainer, but not to this degree. So you might get some damp (and eventually stinky) Vive foam.

Second, as a few other reviews point out, you move around a *lot* in this game. I've yanked the Vive's cable from its little dock with my feet three times now. And I've pulled out my earplugs an equal number of times. It's frantic, and you pivot around constantly. Plus, ducking and weaving and dodging out of the way. I did find that after playing for an hour or so, my brain started to somehow process where I was in the real world while paying attention in the virtual world, and things got a little better. I found myself raising my feet, anticipating where the cord would be. Or turning counter-clockwise after turning clockwise a few times to untangle the cord. And I also found myself relaxing a bit and being less spazzy overall after playing for a while, which also helps.

I kind of expected that VR games would give me the whoas, and be really cool things to show off to friends. I had no idea that some $8 launch title would also fall into that rare category of game where if I have 10 free minutes I'll go fire it up, thinking "OK, time for just one round..." This game does that.

23060090.review:
[b]Game is [u]not[/u] in early access[/b]

[b]What is Holopoint?[/b]
Holopoint is a HTC Vive VR game where you shoot blue cubes with a bow and arrow. Seems simple untill they start shooting back. The idea is that you have eyes in the back of yor head so you can both eliminate cubes for points and avoid cubes shooting at you. When a cube dies it more often than not shoots you, when a cube turns orange it shoots you. How do you avoud these shots? You dodge, duck, dip, dive and dodge your way around them. Also there is samurai and ninjas.

[b]Is Holopoint good?[/b]
Holopoint has amassed an impressive 97% positive feedback and with good reason, it is simple but fun. You need no archery skill and it works well even in a relatively small space and for a measly £5 pricetag it is tempting to say no to.
For how cheap the game is and for how much fun and exercise you and some friends can get I think that Holopoint is very much worth it

[b]Is anything bad?[/b]
If i'm nitpicking then i'd say that there is no real tutorial and that it was frustrating realising that physical movement is required to progress in this game (which is a lot to ask from a nerd), only other points are perhaps the lack of bow options or any kind of features that would make the game more complex. But I can't really complain for the pricetag.

22989753.review:
I am very conflicted about this game.

On the one hand...it is fun as hell.

On the other, it requires motions that could possibly damage your equipment. 

Specifically pulling an arrow from the quiver, and dodging. Let me explain.

Normally these actions would not be a big deal. The problem stems from the pace of the game...which is super fast paced and with dodging. 

First: when you go to pull an arrow from the quiver (on your back) the vive controller tends to clip my headphones (I use over the ear can style 7.1 surround sound...NOT CHEAP headphones!), and since the pace is so fast...I tend to hit them pretty hard violently knocking them from my head. I am worried I will break my vive controler and/or a $200 set of headphones.

Second: The enemies shoot back when you hitt hem with an arrow. They do this so quickly that you havbe to move your head VERY fast to dodge the return shot. If you wear large can style headphones like I do, this allmost throws them across the room. Not cool.

$8 game vs $200 headset or $1000 VR rig....you decide.

TL;DR This game needs to chill a bit out with the action or you will break your headset/VR equipment. Ditch the back quiver and split second return shots. Love the game, hate the motions.

You can expect pure adrenaline from a feeling of total immersion as you do increasingly more at once, from shooting arrows to dodging projectiles aimed right at your head to looking out for incoming ninjas. Don't underestimate the difference a 360 degree threat makes when it comes to effort involved. You literally have to turn around as fast as you can constantly. Suddenly you'll hear a pulse sound growing more intense, as you frantically try and find out which direction it's coming from. You turn around and look up, only to have a projectile hit you right in the face - or dodge it just in time if you're lucky.

And all of this is non-stop, escalating in intensity with every level.

Really, this has GOT to be one of the most enjoyable ways to combine gaming and cardio, and it's definitely worth the asking price!

22658977.review:
Of all the Virtual Reality games I have in my library, this is hands down the favorite of most of the people I know, myself included. The controls are very intuitive... boiling down to simply knocking the arrow with the trigger, drawing, and releasing the arrow by releasing the trigger. Move in room-scale to dip, duck, and lean to avoid enemy fire. The intensity of this game is currently unmatched! You will break a sweat. You will love every second of it. Holopoint is played at the start and end of every VR session. Often times my friends will stop playing a game, after having exhausted it, and come back to holopoint again and again.

Gameplay Breakdown:
You are in a dojo and your room-scale play area is a mat. You can not leave the matt. Enemies will spawn in 360 degrees around you. You must shoot them with your bow while dodging their counter-fire by dipping, ducking, and moving about your play area. Very simple control scheme and solid bowplay.

Pros:
+Most solid archery I have played yet.
+Hitboxes are perfect.
+Nonstop balls to the wall action with a very pleasing difficulty curve.
+It's so intuitive you're garunteed to understand it immediately.
+Immense replayability.

Cons:

22549620.review:
Holopoint is a lot of fun, and I recommend giving it a try- however, I have a problem with it that a few others are having. LAG. 

Yes, 90fps is pretty much necessary for VR games, but this game doesn't want to cooperate. It's not even that graphically intense of a game, so why am I getting tons of lag playing it? 

My computer has a beast of a CPU. 5930k at 4ghz. My GPU is a little below recommended, but it's fine for basically all the other VR games I have played. A GTX 780. That's basically as good as a 970, and yet I can't handle playing Holopoint? 

Besides the performance problems, this game is pretty cool. Shooting arrows is a little different than The Lab though- the trajectory of the arrow is determined by your "bow hand", meaning you can angle your bow hand to change the direction of the shot. This is different than The Lab which changes the arrow trajectory based on the combination of your draw hand and your bow hand. The Lab does it more "Realistic" compared to Holopoint, but that doesn't make Holopoint bad necessarily It’s just not preferred. Also, the arrows go MUCH straighter than “The Lab” which has a lot of arch to their shots, and travel slower. These arrows travel much more straight, and faster. This means you can be more precise with them. It’s pretty satisfying actually.

That being said, the game itself is going to be a workout at first. With each enemy you shoot with an arrow, you get a projectile that launches at you and you must dodge. This is a little jarring at first, but it does make the game very… Dynamic. You are constantly moving, and it adds a layer of intensity that wouldn’t be there otherwise. This game is as much of a shooting game as it is a dodging game, love it or hate it. I don’t know how I feel about it, but I think I like it overall. It’s not “passive” like The Lab, which the player sees virtually no threat to one’s self. 

If the LAG wasn’t so bad, I would like the game MUCH more, but alas, I don’t want to play it as much because of the framerate issues. I wish I could lower graphical settings, but this game doesn’t have any settings to configure that I can see.

It’s a very arcade experience, but it’s a pretty cool one. I’d give it a shot, and if you feel like the framerate isn’t where it needs to be, than perhaps return it.

22537978.review:
While Holopoints look alot of rudamentary compared to similar titles, such as Space pirate simulator; SPT is a light warmup compared to what you will encounter in Holopoint.

You starting with shooting at cubes... Sounds boring right? Not as simple as it sounds. The moment you hit one, it retaliates and shoots back as they shatter. And if you leave them around for too long... they also shoot. This goes on with every increasing amounts and eventually you simply cannot hit them all before one shoots without you hitting it first... and thats when things change radically and new types of enemies start relentlessly be thrown, a suprise after another. And no, there are no shields, so no turtleing, and you have to dodge all the projectiles.

 Thats when things get really interesting and accuracy becomes very important. 

And its not just Point and shoot, you have to use both your hands to align your shots at your target, and coordinate with the other to reach the quever. You will feel even more bad *** when you manage to hit multiple targets in a row.

I highly recommend this to anyone that the space to go side to side in, and has the physical fitness to play it: but do pull off some practise on turning with the head set on. There is a danger of getting tangled with the headset if one keeps turning a single direction. The game is really intense, and at its price, fully worth it.

My current feedback:
- It could use more variation in the music played back, 
- Arrows do not seem to be able to be used as a thrusting meelee weapon.
- Could use a vibration queue indicating that an arrow has been grabbed from the quever
- What is the indication of what health is remaining for player?

This is currently my favorite Vive title.  At first I thought it was dull, but that was pre-level 10 when I was only shooting stationary cubes.  Now that I'm up to 27 it's a whole different experience.  I literally feel like a 日本の射手 (nihon no ite -> japanese archer) practicing 弓道 (kyudo -> "way of the bow") in my own personal dojo.  My only complaints are that the samurai become invulnerable once they begin their attack animation, and their attack is a high swipe so it looks like it should be dodge-able.  The only bug I've experienced is occasionally my arrow will shoot horizontally and do no damage (maybe I'm pulling too sloppy?), and occasionally the start cube doesn't activate when firing on it.  

This game is very similar to Space Pirate Trainer, except there's more diversity in enemy types at the expense of less diversity in attack options.  I also think it's really cool that your arrows start flaming when you get a consecutive hit streak going, although I'm not sure if it changes anything other than visuals.  If you have a Vive, and you enjoy archery then I strongly recommend picking up this game!

22367719.review:
The Lab's Longbow demo got me wanting more VR bow goodness, and Holopoint more than fulfilled that craving. This game has gone straight to the top of my list of Vive launch titles. The difficulty ramp is perfect so far (just hit wave 16, I think) - changing things up just enough as time goes by to keep you pressured (and to get you moving enough to get your heart rate up!), without feeling unfair. I expect that I have a long ways to go before I'm good enough to see all this game has to offer, but I don't plan on stopping any time soon.

I will admit that I'm not sure how this game would play in a tight space - I have about 2.5x2.5 meters and feel like I use it all, but you could probably get away with less with more ducking.

The only problem I have had with the game is one built-in to the Vive - I recently died because I stepped on my cable and lost USB connection to the computer from the linkbox. Whoops. Try not to make my mistake, and also watch out that you don't spin the same way too many times and get wrapped up in your cable either.

Perhaps a more relaxed setting, for the individual who just wants to take down the pace a notch or two. A setting to only have targets appear in one direction, rather than in a 270* arch. 22273143.review:
One of the first games I tried was Valve's "The Lab". I found myself gravitating towards the Longbow minigame. I liked the act of firing a bow so much that I thought I'd search for more expansive bow and arrow experience. Thats where I came across Holopoint. The mechanics of the game are quite simple, but so enjoyable. Each time I hit a target, it fires back at me, causing me to have to dodge out of the way. This is what makes the action feel so cool. Each shot I take, I immediately move/lean/crouch out of the way and into position for another shot. When you begin to string together shots and position changes, its an incredible and oddly fluid/graceful feeling.

For the price, Holopoint is a pretty fun experience. I experienced no motion sickness, no tracking issues, and had no trouble enjoying the experience. Its a very active game, so prepare to sweat. If you're a fan of the bow and arrow mechanic, I definitely recommend.
